awd_titl_txt: WORKSHOP: Doctoral Consortium at PETRA 2022, The 15th International Conference on Pervasive Technologies Related to Assistive Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
This is funding to support a Doctoral Consortium (workshop) of approximately 10 graduate student authors from U.S. institutions of higher learning, along with distinguished research faculty as mentors (who will not be funded by this proposal), to be held in conjunction with the Fifteenth International Conference on Pervasive Technologies Related to Assistive Environments (PETRA 2022), which will take place June 29-July 1 on the island of Corfu, Greece.  The PETRA mission is to promote interdisciplinary research on ways to use pervasive ambient intelligent environments to improve the quality of life and enhance human performance with greater capabilities.  It is the only annual conference that brings together theoreticians and practitioners from a wide variety of disciplines to focus on the application of pervasive technologies to assistive environments.  Conference outcomes have a broad impact in diverse application areas such as manufacturing, transportation, energy systems, security and safety, robotics, healthcare, biomedicine, environment and conservation.  PETRA brings together very different types of technologies to also address important social and healthcare issues for sensitive populations, such as the elderly, or persons suffering from chronic conditions such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Cerebral Palsy and other disabilities or traumas.  The PETRA proceedings are published in the ACM Digital Library, and the authors of the best papers are invited to submit to special journal issues after the end of the conference.  More information about the conference may be found online at http://www.petrae.org.  The PETRA 2022 Doctoral Consortium will afford student authors of papers accepted for presentation at the conference a unique opportunity to gain additional exposure for their innovative ideas while also receiving reinforcement for the importance and value of conducting research with societal impact.  The workshop will allow the junior participants to create a social network both among themselves and with senior colleagues. The organizing committee will make a concerted effort to attract participants who are women, members of under-represented minorities, and persons with disabilities; to further assure diversity, NSF funds will be used to support no more than 2 student participants from any one institution.  Over the past 14 years, more than 300 graduate and undergraduate students from U.S. educational institutions have been able to benefit from NSF support of the PETRA Doctoral Consortia.

The goals of the Doctoral Consortium, which will consist of special sessions at the beginning, during, and at the end of the conference, are to increase the exposure and visibility of the participants' work within the community, to help establish a sense of community among this next generation of researchers, and to help foster their research efforts by providing substantive feedback and guidance in a supportive and interactive environment from a group of senior researchers.  The special program organized for the students includes sessions between the doctoral students and the faculty mentors, in which the students will discuss their work and ask questions; the faculty mentors will provide constructive comments on the students' work and address their questions.  Each student will be asked to submit a report that provides feedback about the conference, regarding the benefits they received, which presentations they liked and why, and how certain papers and topics relate to their work. After they finish these reports, students will participate in small group breakout sessions to discuss them, and the faculty mentors will provide guidance on how to proceed for further journal publication.  Students will also have the option to submit a poster paper and to attend conference workshops on special topics.  Short papers on the participants' work will be published in the conference proceedings, and a summary report on the event will be posted on the conference website.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Award Title: WORKSHOP: Doctoral Consortium at PETRA 2022, The 15th International Conference on Pervasive Technologies Related to Assistive Environments 

PI: Fillia Makedon
Awardee: University of Texas at Arlington 
Award Number: 2219802

Award Ends: 03/31/2025
Program Officer Name: Dan Cosley 

Email Address: dcosley@nsf.gov

PETRA 2022 was the fifteenth (15th) international conference on PErvasive Technologies Related to Assistive Environments. This is an interdisciplinary conference was launched in 2008.  It focused on pervasive technologies and assistive environments to enhance human performance. It merged expertise from disciplines such as, sensors, human computer interaction, Artificial Intelligence (AI), human robot interaction, computer vision, user interfaces, rehabilitation, cognitive computing, neuroscience, disability computing, and other areas. The results potentially impact environments at home, in the workplace and in public spaces. Papers were published at the ACM digital library ICPS proceedings. 

The objective of the conference was to stimulate interdisciplinary research that will help develop effective Assistive Technologies (AT) to improve the quality of life and overcome physical, cognitive, and operational obstacles that prevent a human from reaching his/her full potential and achieve best performance.  Findings addressed the needs of persons with special needs, such as providing safe in-home care for the blind vets, persons with paralysis, persons with Dementia, Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, chronic arthritis, PTSD, low vision, and other conditions. Computational and computer engineering advancements were presented on how to improve functional capabilities and human productivity.

Conference results addressed diverse application areas such as, manufacturing safety, telehealth, vocational assessment, robot-based rehabilitation and training, public and personal safety, transportation, virtual reality for executive function assessment, neuroscience, and other applications. AI methods were on smart homes, physiological monitoring, wearables, mental health, gaming, gait analysis for motor disabilities, and in domains such as education, psychology, neuroscience, robotics and other. 

PETRA 2022 had 130 attendees, three keynote speakers, 9 conference sessions and 13 workshop sessions. There were 8 awards, for Best Paper for Novelty, Best Student Paper, Best Technical Paper, Best Workshop Paper, Best Workshop Student Paper, Best Poster Paper, Best Poster Student Paper, and Best Demo Paper.

The 2022 Doctoral Consortium (DC) supported 17 student authors from 10 different US institutions. Some DC authors received additional funding from the Univ. of Texas Arlington College of Engineering.  Special DC sessions for the benefit of the NSF DC scholars took place to describe their work, exchange ideas and discuss challenges and opportunities in doing interdisciplinary research and receive feedback from participating faculty mentors. Discussion issues were on ways to make good progress with the Ph.D., designing good experiments, and good teamwork.  Benefits for the DC scholars included:

  • Presented their work to experts and received valuable feedback on ways to advance their research.  
  • Gained experience on how to improve their presentation style and build confidence from this experience.
  • Networked with students from other universities and shared ideas and approaches.
  • Received mentoring by assistive technology experts.
  • Published their scientific contributions widely through the ACM Digital Library proceedings. 

Conclusion: The conference was very successful and beneficial to the DC scholars, in helping them prepare for their future career. The DC funding highlighted the support of NSF towards young researchers and gave visibility to the US institutions where the students came from. The aims of the project were achieved, and the scope of the proposed work has been completed.  The PI does not anticipate any further action on this award.
